study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on quality of life (QoL) and its association with self-care in patients with diabetic foot ulcers.
results_summary: The LG1 group (10 J/cm²) showed the highest proportion of healing and significant associations between QoL domains (physical limitations, pain, general health status) and self-care practices. LLLT overall improved QoL in functional capacity, vitality, and pain domains.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers.
effective_dosage: 10 J/cm² (LG1), 8 J/cm² (LG2), 4 J/cm² (LG3), administered twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) enhances osseointegration and secondary stability of immediately loaded dental implants with connective tissue grafts in patients with buccal bone dehiscence.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved secondary implant stability in the buccolingual dimension but not in the mesiodistal dimension. No significant differences were found between the laser and control groups in secondary stability, gingival thickness, or vertical bone gain, and all implants were successful without complications.
population_specificity: Patients with buccal bone dehiscence requiring dental implants (n=10, split into intervention and control groups).
effective_dosage: 940 nm gallium-aluminum-arsenide laser (specific power/dosage not detailed).
study_duration: 12 weeks (secondary stability measured at this endpoint).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on osteoclast differentiation, functional gene expression, molecular signaling pathways, and orthodontic tooth movement in clinical settings.
results_summary: LLLT promoted RANKL-dependent osteoclast differentiation and increased expression of osteoclast functional genes (MMP9, NFATc1, TRAP, CTSK) in RAW264.7 cells. Clinically, the laser group showed significantly greater cumulative tooth movement over 90 days compared to the control group.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 cell line (precursor for osteoclasts) and 12 human participants in the clinical study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and gaseous ozone on medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaws (MRONJ) following tooth extraction in rats under zoledronic acid therapy.
results_summary: LLLT and ozone groups showed significantly higher bone formation compared to the control group, with no significant difference between LLLT and ozone. The sham group (no zoledronic acid) exhibited the greatest bone formation.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats receiving zoledronic acid therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified for LLLT; zoledronic acid was administered weekly at 0.06 mg/kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in promoting wound healing in patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) and uncontrolled diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT improved wound tissue growth in a patient with DFU after 12 weeks of therapy, with no significant adverse effects reported. The therapy was described as minimally invasive, easy-to-use, and inexpensive.
population_specificity: A 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus, diabetic neuropathy, and diabetic foot ulcer, with uncontrolled blood sugar levels (HbA1C of 9.3%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the penetration efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) using 830 nm continuous waves with various settings and different application techniques through buccal tissue in cats.
results_summary: The study found that extraoral application of LLLT demonstrated detectable penetration efficacy through buccal tissue with both contact and non-contact skin (<10 mm), with no significant difference in mean output power between fluences of 2 and 6 J/cm². The absence of media resulted in significantly higher mean output power compared to alcohol but was not significantly different from normal saline solution.
population_specificity: Twenty-four healthy cats.
effective_dosage: 830 nm wavelength, 200 mW output power, fluences of 2 and 6 J/cm² in continuous-wave mode.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for skin rejuvenation, specifically targeting melasma and wrinkles.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in skin rejuvenation, including melasma reduction and wrinkle improvement, with no reported adverse effects or re-pigmentation. Patient satisfaction scores were also positive.
population_specificity: Thirty Syrian female patients aged 25-50 with moderate to severe melasma and wrinkles.
effective_dosage: 660 nm wavelength, 15.6 mW/cm² power density, 3 J/cm² dose, 32 cm² effective area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation in treating symptomatic Temporomandibular Disorders.
results_summary: The study was retracted due to ethical approval discrepancies and retrospective clinical trial registration, so no valid results can be reported.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic Temporomandibular Disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a complementary treatment for Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) by assessing its effects on lesion resolution, immune response, and fungal viability.
results_summary: LLLT reduced cell influx to the infection site but increased activation of remaining cells, enhancing pro-inflammatory cytokine production and fungicidal activity. It also improved infection resolution and promoted healing by increasing fibrocyte presence.
population_specificity: Mice with subcutaneous air pouch infections of *P. brasiliensis*.
effective_dosage: LLLT irradiation on alternate days (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on the rate of en masse retraction of upper anterior teeth and associated root resorption in adult women with bimaxillary dentoalveolar protrusion.
results_summary: LLLT significantly increased the rate of tooth retraction (0.833 mm/month vs. 0.526 mm/month) and reduced root resorption compared to the control group, but the clinical relevance was deemed insufficient to justify its routine use. Pain scores were comparable between groups.
population_specificity: 36 adult women with bimaxillary dentoalveolar protrusion and Class I Angle molar relationship.
effective_dosage: LLLT applied on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 after extraction, then biweekly until retraction completion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and therapeutic ultrasound combined with home-based exercise versus home-based exercise alone in treating subacromial impingement syndrome (SAIS).
results_summary: LLLT combined with home-based exercise showed significant short-term improvements in activity pain and shoulder function compared to exercise alone, but no long-term benefits were observed at three months. Therapeutic ultrasound did not provide additional benefits over exercise alone at any time point.
population_specificity: 60 patients (19 males, 41 females; mean age 51.3±10.4 years) with subacromial impingement syndrome.
effective_dosage: LLLT was applied five times a week for a total of 15 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could improve the quality of life in women with Lichen sclerosus (LS) who had insufficient response to topical treatment.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in seven of eight quality-of-life domains after ten LLLT treatments. The DoloTest results were significant across most groups, except for smokers.
population_specificity: 100 women with Lichen sclerosus (median age 62) who had poor response to topical treatment.
effective_dosage: 808 nm and 500 mW, ten treatments (first four at twice weekly, remaining six at once weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain and improving functional capability in patients with osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint (CMC1) of the thumb.
results_summary: The study found that while both the LLLT and control groups showed improvement after four weeks of treatment, the reduction in pain and increase in functional capability were not statistically significant (p-value ≥0.5). LLLT combined with conventional treatment was not significantly more effective than conventional treatment alone.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint (CMC1) of the thumb, primarily in their fifties.

study_goal: To evaluate the comparative effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) versus Muscle Energy Technique (MET) in improving shoulder function, pain, and psychological parameters among diabetic patients with frozen shoulder.
results_summary: The study aims to compare LLLT and MET for frozen shoulder in diabetic patients, assessing shoulder function, pain, range of motion, and quality of life, but results are not yet available as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with frozen shoulder.
effective_dosage: Treatment administered three times weekly (specific laser dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of home-based rehabilitation, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), with other treatments like occlusal splints or centre-based rehabilitation for temporomandibular joint disorders (TMD).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT was superior to home-based rehabilitation in pain relief at short-term follow-up, though the evidence certainty was low or very low. No clinically significant differences were observed between home-based rehabilitation and splints for pain intensity, mouth opening, sleep quality, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular joint disorders (TMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the overall efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in managing pain associated with Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS) through a systematic review of existing literature.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain or burning sensation in 5 out of 9 included studies, with effects persisting at two- and four-month follow-ups in 2 studies. However, the authors noted the need for future studies with standardized methodology to strengthen evidence.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS).
study_duration: Follow-ups at two and four months were mentioned, but exact intervention duration was not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in modulating biophoton activity and mitigating oxidative stress, with implications for treating neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that LLLT may modulate biophoton emission and reduce oxidative stress, offering potential therapeutic benefits for neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. The dual signaling system involving biophotons could improve neuronal synchronization and information transfer.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on neurodegenerative diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of transcranial photobiomodulation (tPBM) as a treatment for stroke by summarizing recent findings from animal studies and clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that tPBM enhances mitochondrial function, reduces inflammation, improves blood flow, and promotes neurogenesis, demonstrating efficacy in stroke treatment. However, challenges in translation and the need for further validation were noted.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (both animal models and human clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-level laser therapy (HLLT) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on post-dry needling soreness (PNS), pain, range of motion (ROM), and neck disability index (NDI) in patients with chronic neck pain.
results_summary: Both LLLT and HLLT improved PPT and nVAS scores, with LLLT showing significant pain reduction immediately after treatment and both therapies preventing immediate PNS increase. All groups showed improved VAS, NDI, and ROM 48 hours post-treatment, though the placebo group had increased nVAS after treatment.
population_specificity: 48 women aged 18-35 with chronic neck pain.
study_duration: One session of DN and laser therapy, with follow-ups at 24 and 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on preventing and repairing orthodontically induced inflammatory root resorption (OIIRR) in rats by assessing DSPP expression levels and root resorption volume.
results_summary: LLLT showed a preventive effect on OIIRR, with lower resorption volumes in treated groups compared to untreated groups. However, its reparative effect was limited, as there was no significant difference in DSPP levels between retention groups with and without LLLT.
population_specificity: 6-week-old male Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the application and mechanisms of photobiomodulation (PBM) in treating diabetes and its complications, assessing its advantages and disadvantages.
results_summary: The study suggests PBM is efficacious for a wide range of organ damage related to diabetes, though traditional treatments still face limitations in efficacy and side effects. The abstract highlights PBM's potential but does not provide detailed outcomes.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with complications such as retinopathy, foot ulcers, peripheral neuropathy, and periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of laser therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, on disease severity, facial asymmetry, and facial function in patients with Bell's palsy.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that laser therapy significantly improved disease severity, facial asymmetry, and facial function compared to control care and outperformed electrical stimulation in improving facial severity. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Adult patients with Bell's palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the applications and benefits of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in dentistry, focusing on its ability to stimulate cellular function, promote healing, and reduce pain without thermal damage.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT effectively manages pain and inflammation, promotes healing, and enhances patient comfort without causing thermal damage. It highlights LLLT as a valuable tool for pain management and tissue repair in dental procedures.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dental applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in treating dry socket symptoms compared to the traditional Alvogyl treatment.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that LLLT was superior to Alvogyl in reducing pain, with a statistically significant mean difference of -2.01 (95% CI: -2.43 to -1.59) on the third day of treatment. However, the evidence does not conclusively establish LLLT as a complete substitute for conventional therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with dry socket (alveolitis) following tooth extraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate and 1-month post-treatment effects of PBM (Low-Level Laser Therapy) and TENS on pain intensity in individuals with neck pain.
results_summary: The combination of PBM and TENS improved pain intensity during movement and global perceived effect, but PBM alone was not effective for reducing pain intensity at rest. TENS reduced local and distant hyperalgesia.
population_specificity: Individuals with neck pain (144 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (10 treatment sessions over 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of laser treatment modalities in reducing postoperative pain compared to conventional methods after primary and secondary root canal treatments in permanent mature teeth.
results_summary: The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis, employing a random-effects model to estimate the overall effect measure, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome data regarding the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing primary and secondary root canal treatments in permanent mature teeth.

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) combined with low-level laser therapy (LLLT) against other periodontal regeneration modalities.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for LLLT, only mentioning it as one of the compared modalities in Group V without detailed findings.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal intrabony defects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) in preventing chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis in pediatric patients with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.
results_summary: The study found that Photobiomodulation significantly reduced the incidence and severity of oral mucositis compared to the control group, with higher rates of healthy oral mucosa in the laser group at various follow-up intervals (days 5, 12, 19, and 30). The effect sizes were substantial (0.576–0.796), and results were statistically significant (P-value <0.001).
population_specificity: Forty-two children diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) receiving chemotherapy at a hospital in Cairo, Egypt.
effective_dosage: Diode laser (660nm, 15watt, 10 seconds) once daily for five consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Photobiomodulation (PBM) in managing shoulder and neck pain and disability.
results_summary: The review found promising results for PBM therapy, particularly in pain relief and functional improvements, with infrared wavelengths being the most commonly used. However, variability in PBM protocols and underrepresentation of chronic/complex conditions indicate a need for further standardized trials.
population_specificity: Patients with shoulder and neck conditions, including Subacromial Impingement Syndrome (SAIS) and Myofascial Pain Syndrome (MPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of intraoral photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) on pain associated with local anaesthetic injections in dentistry.
results_summary: Intraoral PBMT significantly reduced pain perception during local anaesthetic injections, with consistent effects in both paediatric and adult populations. Optimal pain reduction was associated with wavelengths of 900-980 nm and irradiation times of 13-40 seconds.
population_specificity: Paediatric and adult dental patients receiving local anaesthetic injections.
effective_dosage: Wavelengths between 900-980 nm, irradiation time of 13-40 seconds.
study_duration: Single session (duration not specified beyond irradiation time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy and other modalities in improving outcomes and reducing costs for lymphedema secondary to cancer.
results_summary: The study found mixed results for low-level laser therapy, with intervention effects ranging from clinically insignificant to large effects on lymphedema volume. Evidence mapping suggested potential benefits when added to complex decongestive therapy in the intensive reduction phase.
population_specificity: Primarily individuals with lymphedema secondary to breast cancer (93% of trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a personalized dosimetry model for photobiomodulation therapy in treating orofacial pain and tension headache by analyzing the relationship between photobiomodulation effects and anthropometric/hemodynamic variables.
results_summary: The study proposes a Monte Carlo simulation model to calculate appropriate dosimetry for photobiomodulation therapies, but specific efficacy results are not yet reported as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: 180 participants with post-COVID orofacial pain and tension headache.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of laser adjuvant therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for managing postoperative endodontic pain.
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy showed reduced pain scores at 24 and 48 hours (SMD = -0.86 and -0.64, respectively), but no significant reduction in pain incidence rates was observed. The study concluded that laser adjuvant therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, positively impact pain intensity reduction.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing endodontic treatment (892 patients for pain scores, 422 for pain prevalence).
study_duration: Pain outcomes measured at 12, 24, and 48 hours post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with other conservative treatments for temporomandibular joint disorders (TMD) in improving pain and maximal mouth opening.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant improvement in pain (SMD: -2.12) and modest improvement in maximal mouth opening (SMD: 0.63), though the certainty of evidence was very low. It was ranked among the effective treatments alongside self-exercise and stabilization splints.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with TMD-related myalgia or arthralgia according to DC/TMD and RDC/TMD criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (Nd:YAG laser) for tinnitus in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: One RCT analyzed low-level laser therapy's effectiveness, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome details. The study concluded that a multidisciplinary non-invasive approach is the most efficacious treatment for tinnitus in TMD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with tinnitus and TMD diagnosed through DC/TMD criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively evaluate the effects of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) using four wavelength ranges (blue, green, red, near-infrared) on sperm cell characteristics in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Most studies showed PBMT had a positive effect on sperm cell motility, with varying effectiveness across different wavelength ranges (6% blue, 10% green, 53% red, 31% NIR). The review highlights PBMT's potential for improving sperm characteristics but notes a need for further biochemical and molecular studies.
population_specificity: Human and animal sperm cells (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: To review current literature and synthesize clinical outcomes related to different low-level laser techniques as a complement to basic periodontal therapy (BPT).
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed that BPT combined with photobiomodulation reduced probing depth and improved clinical attachment levels at various follow-up periods. Transgingival application was particularly effective.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing basic periodontal therapy for periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Frequency ranged from 1 to 9 sessions, with wavelengths of infrared (89% in intrasulcular techniques) and red (61.5% in transgingival techniques).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 5 days to 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) as an adjuvant treatment for recurrent herpes labialis (RHL) in combination with acyclovir cream.
results_summary: PBMT combined with acyclovir significantly reduced pain intensity within two to three days and lesion size by days 7 and 10 compared to acyclovir alone. Patients in the PBMT group reported higher treatment satisfaction.
population_specificity: 22 symptomatic patients with recurrent herpes labialis (RHL).
effective_dosage: 940±10 nm wavelength, 4 J/cm² (specific frequency not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combined Er:YAG laser (ERL) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with single laser applications and traditional scaling and root planing (SRP) for non-surgical periodontal treatment.
results_summary: For moderate periodontal pockets, combined ERL+SRP+LLLT and single laser treatments (ERL+SRP, SRP+LLLT) showed greater probing depth reduction and clinical attachment level improvement compared to SRP alone at 3 and 6 months. For deep pockets, only the combined ERL+SRP+LLLT group outperformed SRP alone. No significant differences were observed in bleeding, plaque, inflammatory cytokines, or pathogens among groups.
population_specificity: 25 non-smoking patients with Stage II or Stage III periodontitis.
study_duration: 6 months (assessed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) in treating musculoskeletal disorders.
results_summary: The study found no statistical differences between LLLT and HILT in most outcomes, but LLLT showed superiority in increasing grip strength, while HILT was more effective in improving certain structural parameters like biceps diameter and supraspinatus thickness.
population_specificity: 704 participants with various musculoskeletal disorders, including tennis elbow, carpal tunnel syndrome, chronic low back pain, knee arthritis, plantar fasciitis, and subacromial impingement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) combined with home exercise versus peloid therapy plus exercise and exercise alone on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with subacromial impingement syndrome (SIS).
results_summary: LLLT combined with home exercise showed statistically significant improvements in pain (VAS), functional status (SPADI), quality of life (SF-36), and range of motion (ROM) post-treatment and at 1-month follow-up, with effects comparable to peloid therapy plus exercise. The exercise-only group also improved in ROM and SF-36 physical components.
population_specificity: 168 patients diagnosed with subacromial impingement syndrome (SIS).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of photobiomodulation therapy (PBM) in enhancing bone integration with dental implants.
results_summary: PBM showed potential to improve implant stability (measured via Periotest) and bone density, but no significant difference was found in implant stability quotients (ISQ), marginal bone loss, or implant survival rates between PBM and control groups.
population_specificity: 571 patients undergoing dental implant procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nonpharmacological therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, in improving nutrition status and reducing complications in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy was found to be effective in improving body weight loss and reducing the incidence of severe oral mucositis and gastrointestinal complications during radiotherapy, though it had no significant impact on quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety and effectiveness of fractionated and low-level laser therapy for gynecologic conditions, including vulvovaginal atrophy, lichen sclerosus, and urinary incontinence.
results_summary: The study found weak evidence supporting fractionated laser therapy for vaginal atrophy and lichen sclerosus, with no strong evidence for urinary incontinence or low-level laser therapy for chronic pelvic pain. Short-term trials suggest benefits, but larger, long-term, randomized trials are needed.
population_specificity: Women with gynecologic conditions such as genitourinary syndrome of menopause, lichen sclerosus, and urinary incontinence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on wound healing and postoperative discomfort after palatal ASTG removal.
results_summary: LLLT improved wound healing and reduced postoperative pain and analgesic consumption. The study noted that the methodological quality of the systematic reviews on LLLT was variable, with some classified as low or critically low.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing palatal ASTG removal for periodontal or peri-implant surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of photobiomodulation (PBM) as a therapeutic intervention for Alzheimer's disease by targeting gut microbiota and immune modulation.
results_summary: The study suggests that PBM may restore gut microbiota balance and modulate immune responses, potentially alleviating AD-associated dysbiosis and neurodegeneration. However, specific clinical outcomes or statistical significance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Alzheimer's disease patients (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of combining photobiomodulation (PBM) with orofacial myofunctional therapy (OMT) in managing orofacial pain disorders.
results_summary: The combined approach of PBM and OMT showed a pronounced impact on reducing pain and enhancing functional activity in patients with orofacial disorders, with 7 out of 10 RCTs supporting this finding. One study reported significant increases in pressure pain threshold for specific muscles post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with orofacial pain disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether diode laser-based photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) could expedite the resolution of soft tissue anesthesia in children receiving inferior alveolar nerve block (IANB) injections.
results_summary: The study found that PBMT reduced the duration of lip anesthesia by 11.66 minutes compared to sham laser treatment, with no significant difference in soft tissue trauma between groups. The results were statistically significant (P < 0.001).
population_specificity: Children aged 6-9 requiring pulpotomy procedures on both sides of the mandible.
effective_dosage: 808 nm, 250 mW, 23s continuous, 0.5 cm², 11.5 J/cm², applied to two points at the injection site and ten points along the infra-alveolar nerve's pathway.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for the prevention or treatment of oral mucositis (OM) grade ≥II in pediatric patients undergoing chemo/radiotherapy or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT was not effective for preventing or treating OM grade ≥II, showing no significant benefit in reducing the risk of severe OM. The therapeutic application of LLLT also did not demonstrate meaningful clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing chemo/radiotherapy or HSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with levothyroxine on thyroid function, oxidative stress, and quality of life in Hashimoto's thyroiditis patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study examined LLLT's impact on thyroid function, oxidative stress, and quality of life in HT patients.
population_specificity: 46 patients diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and laser acupuncture therapy (LAT) in reducing pain after initial orthodontic archwire placement.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain reduction between LLLT, LAT, ibuprofen, and placebo laser treatment. Pain intensity peaked within the first two days post-archwire placement and diminished by the seventh day.
population_specificity: 60 female patients requiring premolar extractions for orthodontic crowding.
study_duration: Pain was monitored up to seven days post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Photobiomodulation Therapy (PBMT) on muscle performance in people with multiple sclerosis (pwMS), both in the short-term and over an extended period.
results_summary: High-dose PBMT improved force recovery in the short-term, and individualized PBMT doses significantly improved muscle strength over two weeks, though muscle fatigue and endurance time did not show significant improvement.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with mild-moderate multiple sclerosis (N = 17 in study I, N = 12 in study II).
effective_dosage: 40 J, 80 J, 120 J in study I; individualized doses (based on best dose-effect from study I) in study II.
study_duration: Single session in study I; two weeks in study II.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mechanisms, applications, and potential benefits of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in periodontal care, including its role in improving treatment outcomes and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT (photobiomodulation) enhances periodontal treatment outcomes, expedites soft tissue wound healing, reduces inflammation, and mitigates post-surgery discomfort. It also highlighted the need for further clinical research to optimize laser procedures and develop antimicrobial photodynamic therapy.
population_specificity: Individuals receiving periodontal care, including those undergoing regenerative procedures or post-surgery recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) improves quadriceps strength and endurance torques in asymptomatic adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between photobiomodulation and sham interventions in improving maximum isometric torque or endurance torques, with mean differences below the minimal detectable change.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic adults (n=28, randomized into two groups of 14 each).
effective_dosage: 170 mW for 240 seconds per session, applied over four consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the parameters, mechanisms, and effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) in regulating bone repair and its clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that PBM, using wavelengths of 635-980 nm, output power of 40-100 mW, and energy density below 100 J/cm², shows promise in accelerating bone repair. It highlighted PBM's non-invasive and painless advantages but did not provide detailed clinical outcome data.
population_specificity: Not specified (general bone repair context).
effective_dosage: Wavelength 635-980 nm, output power 40-100 mW, energy density <100 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in treating allergic rhinitis (AR), comparing it to placebo and other treatments.
results_summary: LLLT alleviated nasal symptoms and improved quality of life in AR patients, but the effect may be due to placebo, as it did not significantly outperform placebo in direct comparisons. The analysis had significant publication bias and heterogeneity.
population_specificity: People with allergic rhinitis (AR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of different lasers in preventing enamel demineralization in high caries risk cases, such as around orthodontic brackets, restorations, and caries-susceptible pits and fissures.
results_summary: The study found that low-power CO2 laser irradiation significantly reduced the incidence of white spot lesions (WSLs) in enamel, with a standardized mean difference of 0.21 (95% CI: 0.15-0.30, p < 0.00001). The meta-analysis also indicated a positive effect on enamel microhardness in ex-vivo/in situ studies.
population_specificity: High caries risk cases, including patients with orthodontic brackets, restorations, and caries-susceptible pits and fissures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank various treatments, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for painful temporomandibular disc displacement without reduction (DDwoR) in terms of pain reduction and maximum mouth opening.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for LLLT, focusing instead on arthrocentesis with intra-articular injections and conservative treatments. No significant findings or comparisons involving LLLT were highlighted.
population_specificity: Patients with painful temporomandibular disc displacement without reduction (742 participants from 16 RCTs).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for acute low back pain and provide clinical recommendations based on evidence.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT is recommended for acute low back pain, indicating it is an effective treatment option among the reviewed physical therapies. The recommendation was based on systematic reviews and randomized controlled trials, supported by expert consensus.
population_specificity: Patients with acute and sub-acute low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the effect of portable low-level laser therapy in reducing wrist pain and enhancing hand function in patients with wrist pain.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant pain reduction, but only the experimental group demonstrated significant functional improvement. Lateral and pinch strength improved in both groups, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects with wrist pain.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes a day, 5 days per week for 3 weeks (15 sessions total).

study_goal: To evaluate and compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and Low-Intensity Pulsed Ultrasound (LIPUS) in reducing pain induced by orthodontic separation.
results_summary: Both LLLT and LIPUS significantly reduced pain scores compared to the control group at all assessment time points, with no significant difference between the two treatments. The maximum pain level was reached after 24 hours, but both interventions effectively mitigated pain when applied in multiple doses.
population_specificity: 150 patients undergoing orthodontic treatment (145 assessed).
effective_dosage: 20 seconds per point (maxillary and mandibular first molars), 810-nm AlGaAs diode laser, 150 mW output power, 4 J/cm² energy density, applied at 5 min, 24 h, and 48 h post-separator placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) when added to conventional treatments for improving median nerve cross-sectional area and pain in mild-to-moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) patients.
results_summary: LLLT combined with conventional treatments significantly improved median nerve cross-sectional area (mild effect) and pain (substantial effect), with comparable efficacy to ESWT. No significant differences were found between LLLT and ESWT in pain relief or nerve CSA reduction.
population_specificity: Mild-to-moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) patients

study_goal: To assess whether low-level laser therapy improves the quality of life in patients with xerostomia undergoing head and neck radiotherapy.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy improved dry mouth sensation and quality of life, with observed increases in stimulated and unstimulated salivary flow. The results were consistent across multiple studies, though the sample size was limited.
population_specificity: Patients with xerostomia induced by head and neck radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Infrared wavelength (two studies combined with red wavelength; specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether phonophoresis and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) provided additional benefits to tendon and nerve gliding exercises in treating moderate Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with exercise improved clinical and ultrasonographic parameters in moderate CTS patients, but no additional benefit was observed compared to exercise alone. All groups showed improvement, suggesting exercise therapy alone may be sufficient.
population_specificity: 45 patients with moderate Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of combining 655 nm low-level laser therapy with topical 2% minoxidil for treating female pattern hair loss (FPHL) in a Chinese population.
results_summary: The combination therapy showed statistically significant improvements in mean hair diameter and intermediate hair enlargement in the midscalp area compared to minoxidil alone. Adverse events included mild hair loss, desquamation, pruritus, seborrhea, and hypertrichosis, but were generally manageable.
population_specificity: Chinese females with female pattern hair loss (FPHL).
effective_dosage: 1 ml topical 2% minoxidil solution twice daily + 20 min 655 nm low-level laser helmet once every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two different types of lasers (GRR and Epic10) versus vitamin B in treating lower lip paresthesia after BSSO.
results_summary: Both laser therapies and vitamin B accelerated nerve regeneration, with laser groups showing better healing rates than vitamin B. Although no statistically significant difference was found between the two laser groups, clinical observations favored the GRR laser.
population_specificity: Thirty patients who underwent BSSO and experienced lower lip paresthesia.
effective_dosage: Transcutaneous and transmucosal laser treatments (specific dosage not detailed); vitamin B-complex tablets once daily.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of extra-oral salivary glands photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) in treating xerostomia and hyposalivation caused by radiotherapy.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant improvements in pain reduction and stimulated salivary flow 30 days post-radiotherapy, with wavelengths between 630 and 830 nm and radiant exposure from 2 to 10 J/cm² showing promise. The therapy was deemed safe and beneficial for managing radiotherapy-induced salivary gland dysfunction.
population_specificity: Cancer patients experiencing xerostomia and/or hyposalivation after radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Wavelengths 630-830 nm, radiant exposure 2-10 J/cm² (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of lasers and energy-based devices, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, in minimizing surgical scar formation through a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy was found to be one of the most efficacious treatments for surgical scar minimization, with a weighted mean difference of -3.78 (95% CI -6.32, -1.24), comparable to pulsed dye laser. Both treatments showed significant effectiveness in reducing scar formation.
population_specificity: 482 participants with 671 postsurgical wounds, treated no later than 6 months after surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up period of at least 3 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain induced by orthodontic separation compared to pharmacological methods.
results_summary: LLLT was effective in reducing pain at 6 and 24 hours post-separation, with significant standard mean differences. The pain reduction increased over time, though the evidence was rated as weak to moderate.
population_specificity: Patients receiving elastomeric separators during orthodontic treatment.
study_duration: Pain assessed at 6 and 24 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of low-level laser therapy in facilitating nerve recovery and wound healing after wisdom tooth extraction with mandibular impact.
results_summary: The study compared low-level laser therapy (808 nm, 30 mW, 10 J/cm²) with oral mecobalamin and CGF gel for nerve recovery and wound healing in patients with IAN injury. Results suggested potential benefits of laser therapy, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Thirty-one patients (mean age 27.52 ± 5.79 years) with inferior alveolar nerve injury following wisdom tooth extraction.
effective_dosage: 808 nm, 30 mW, 10 J/cm² (specific frequency not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily PBMT using low-intensity LEDs could improve mobility, muscle strength, and reduce ICU length of stay in critically ill patients.
results_summary: PBMT significantly reduced ICU stay by ~30%, increased mobility (255% vs. 110%), improved muscle strength (MRC: 12% vs. -9%), and enhanced handgrip dynamometry (34% vs. -13%) compared to sham treatment, with no significant difference in SAPS3 scores.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU).
effective_dosage: 2,073.6 Joules per session (207.36 Joules per site, 10 sites, 90s per site) applied daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms of hair follicle development and regeneration and evaluate emerging therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for hair loss management.
results_summary: The study highlights Low-Level Laser Therapy as a promising emerging treatment for hair loss, alongside other regenerative medicine-based therapies, but does not provide specific efficacy data for it.
population_specificity: Individuals with hair loss conditions, including androgenetic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal combination of LLLT parameters for treating breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL) by analyzing existing studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that post-treatment quality of life was significantly better in the axillary group, with the most effective regimen being three times/week at a laser density of 1.5-2 J/cm². However, no single LLLT regimen was conclusively more effective than others.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL) who had completed cancer treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for chronic pain associated with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: The study issued a conditional recommendation against LLLT (alone or in combination with other interventions) for chronic TMD pain, indicating limited efficacy. The recommendation was based on a systematic review and network meta-analysis of available evidence.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain (≥3 months) associated with temporomandibular disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of nonpharmacological interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for postoperative pain relief in coronary artery bypass graft surgery patients.
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy was found to be safe, effective, and well tolerated as an adjuvant to drug treatment for postoperative pain relief. The study noted that nonpharmacological interventions, including laser therapy, demonstrated positive outcomes without significant adverse effects.
population_specificity: Postoperative coronary artery bypass graft surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing local tissue damage and inflammation caused by Bothrops atrox envenomations.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced muscle damage (lower creatine kinase levels), pain intensity, swelling, and edema compared to the control group, with no observed adverse events. However, no significant differences were found in secondary infections, necrosis, or the need for analgesics between groups.
population_specificity: 60 adult patients (87% male, 13% female) with Bothrops atrox envenomations in Manaus, Brazil.
effective_dosage: 4 J/cm² for 40 seconds per application point using a gallium arsenide laser with infrared and red emitters.
study_duration: 48 hours after admission, with disability assessments 4-6 months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the histological, physiological, and biomechanical effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on tendon healing in animal and human models.
results_summary: Animal studies showed LLLT stimulated collagen organization, growth factors, and biomechanical properties while reducing inflammatory markers. Human studies found only post-LLLT anti-inflammatory effects, with uncertain impacts on physiology and biomechanics.
population_specificity: Animal models (50 studies) and human participants (5 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic or placebo effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for temporomandibular disorder (TMD) and compare it with standard treatment methods.
results_summary: All groups showed significant improvement in pain (VAS) and jaw movement indicators, but no significant difference was observed between LLLT, placebo, and standard treatment groups. The study concluded that LLLT cannot replace standard treatment alone.
population_specificity: 42 patients with TMD referred to Kerman Dental School Pain Clinic.
effective_dosage: Gallium-aluminium-arsenide laser treatment twice a week for 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms and effectiveness of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) in orthodontic tooth movement (OTM) and its potential to prevent orthodontically induced inflammatory root resorption (OIIRR).
results_summary: PBMT shows promise in reducing pain, inflammation, and promoting tissue healing during OTM, but its effectiveness in preventing OIIRR is moderate due to challenges in light penetration and energy delivery to the root surface. The study highlights the need for advanced approaches to optimize PBMT application in orthodontics.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment (OT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) in reducing postoperative pain in root canal re-treatment (RCR) cases compared to conventional pharmacologic approaches.
results_summary: The systematic review found that PBMT significantly reduced postoperative pain in RCR cases, with statistically significant improvements at 24, 48, and 72 hours. The mean differences in pain scores were clinically meaningful, and PBMT showed superior results compared to conventional methods.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing root canal re-treatment (RCR) in endodontics.
study_duration: Pain outcomes were measured at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-treatment.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of photobiomodulation (PBM) therapy in relieving pain in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) compared to control/placebo groups and other therapies.
results_summary: PBM was found to be a promising modality for relieving painful symptoms in DPN, particularly when combined with other therapies, improving the quality of life for diabetic patients. The review included 14 studies that met selection criteria out of an initial 1692 citations.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore innovative treatment options, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (PBMT), for pseudoexfoliative glaucoma (PEG).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) could be a promising non-invasive alternative for treating PEG by improving cellular function and promoting tissue repair, though specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with pseudoexfoliative glaucoma (PEG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mitochondrial stimulation occurs in adipose tissue cells after photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT), potentially leading to lipolysis and apoptosis.
results_summary: PBMT resulted in positive mitochondrial antibody signals (cAMP, DRP1, FAS, FIS1, MFN2, OPA1) in adipose tissue compared to controls, suggesting mitochondrial stimulation as a mechanism for lipolysis and apoptosis.
population_specificity: Obese women undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of PBMT-sMF versus placebo on pain reduction, fibromyalgia impact, pain intensity, and treatment satisfaction in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: PBMT-sMF significantly reduced the degree-of-pain rating (tender point count) compared to placebo at the end of treatment and follow-up, with no reported adverse events. The therapy was deemed superior to placebo for fibromyalgia management.
population_specificity: 90 female patients with fibromyalgia.
effective_dosage: Nine treatment sessions, three times a week.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with a follow-up assessment 4 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on the effects of laser therapy, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for treating vulvodynia in women.
results_summary: Three of six studies showed statistically significant pain improvement, while others reported subjective pain reduction. Sexual function improved in two studies, but evidence was limited by small sample sizes and lack of robust controls.
population_specificity: Women with vulvodynia (chronic vulvar pain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT), ultrasound therapy (US), and exercise in improving cervical straightening and reducing pain in children with straight neck syndrome.
results_summary: LLLT combined with exercise showed significant improvement in Cobb angle and pain reduction (VAS), outperforming US plus exercise and exercise alone. The effect was statistically significant (P < 0.001) for LLLT and US groups, while exercise alone showed a lesser effect (P = 0.006).
population_specificity: Children aged 12-18 years diagnosed with cervical straightening due to long-term electronic device use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on burning pain, quality of life, and negative emotions in patients with Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS).
results_summary: LLLT was significantly more effective than placebo or clonazepam in reducing burning pain, but its effects on quality of life and negative emotions were not statistically significant. The meta-analysis suggests LLLT may be beneficial for BMS patients, though further research is needed.
population_specificity: Patients with Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS) (total of 550 participants across 14 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of Nd:YAG laser therapy for treating recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS) lesions and compare focused vs. defocused irradiation techniques.
results_summary: Nd:YAG laser therapy significantly improved pain relief and reduced pain duration compared to placebo, while also decreasing lesion size in treated groups. The placebo group showed an increase in lesion size.
population_specificity: 138 patients (94 males, 44 females) with untreated recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS).
effective_dosage: Focused laser (48 J/cm², 0.797 W/cm², spot size 0.1256 cm²); defocused laser (21 J/cm², 0.354 W/cm², spot size 0.2826 cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ozone and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on postoperative pain after root canal treatment in symptomatic apical periodontitis on vital teeth.
results_summary: LLLT reduced postoperative pain and pain on percussion compared to placebo, with significant differences observed on days 1, 2, and 3. However, LLLT and ozone therapy showed no superiority over each other.
population_specificity: Eighty patients with symptomatic apical periodontitis on vital teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and classify existing evidence on various body contouring methods, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), to help physicians identify the best evidence-based options.
results_summary: The study summarized data on LLLT among 11 body contouring methods, including FDA-approved devices, side effects, and common protocols, but specific findings on LLLT were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing evidence)

study_goal: To investigate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to non-surgical periodontal treatment (NSPT) on the plasminogen-activating system in severe periodontitis.
results_summary: Adjunctive LLLT modulated the plasminogen activating system by altering GCF tPA and PAI-1 levels, leading to reduced plasminogen activation in severe periodontitis patients. Clinical parameters improved, and total GCF tPA levels were affected.
population_specificity: Patients with Stage 3-4 Grade C periodontitis and age-gender-matched healthy individuals.
effective_dosage: LLLT applied on Days 0, 2, and 7 (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in adults with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), focusing on pain, inflammation, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found low-quality evidence suggesting no significant difference between infrared laser and sham treatment for pain, stiffness, or other RA symptoms. Evidence for red laser and laser acupuncture was very uncertain, with insufficient data to support or refute their effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults with rheumatoid arthritis (793 participants across 18 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of photobiomodulation therapy in improving neuropathic pain and plantar pressure distribution in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: Photobiomodulation therapy showed improvement in neuropathic pain and nerve conduction velocity, and it reduced plantar pressure distribution, lowering the risk of foot ulcers. The review included eight studies, indicating consistent positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and photodynamic therapy (PDT) on oral health and periodontal tissue in fixed orthodontic patients, assessing their efficacy relative to conventional plaque removal methods.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant differences between LLLT and control groups in terms of plaque index, bleeding on probing, or other periodontal measures. Limited evidence suggests LLLT may improve oral health, particularly in addressing caries, but further research is needed.
population_specificity: Fixed orthodontic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the use of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for managing acute pain and discuss clinical findings and considerations for its application.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the need for further exploration of non-pharmacological pain management options like LLLT, given the limitations in existing research, but does not provide specific efficacy results.
population_specificity: Adults experiencing acute pain (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) on pain intensity in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain (CNNP), comparing it to a sham laser intervention.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results; it describes the study design and objectives. The study will evaluate pain intensity, range of motion, and disability in CNNP patients after HILT treatment.
population_specificity: Internal and external community members associated with Andrés Bello University suffering from chronic non-specific neck pain.
effective_dosage: Treatments performed twice a week (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank the efficacy of non-pharmacological interventions, including massage therapy, in managing agitation in people with dementia.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy was among the most effective non-pharmacological interventions for reducing agitation in dementia patients, outperforming other methods and controls.
population_specificity: People with dementia experiencing agitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of foot and hand massage on postoperative pain and anxiety in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
results_summary: Foot and hand massage significantly reduced pain intensity and the need for analgesics compared to the control group, and a positive relationship was found between pain reduction and lower anxiety levels.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy between April 2018 and January 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the current state of cancer treatment incorporating Thai traditional medicine (TTM), including massage, and identify systemic problems using the WHO health system framework.
results_summary: The study found that TTM services, including massage, were provided to cancer patients, primarily in outpatient settings, but noted issues such as poor acceptance by other healthcare practitioners and lack of experience among TTM practitioners in treating cancer.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer, caregivers, and service providers from five TTM hospitals in Thailand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to appraise clinical practice guidelines on uncomplicated birth, identifying consensus and non-consensus recommendations, including those related to perineal and uterine massage.
results_summary: The study identified perineal massage and uterine massage as main discrepant recommendations among guidelines, but did not provide specific efficacy or safety outcomes for these interventions.
population_specificity: Guidelines relevant to uncomplicated birth (general obstetric population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of manual therapy (MT) for chronic musculoskeletal pain (CMP) in the upper limbs and thorax of female breast cancer survivors and assess its impact on quality of life and function.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MT reduced CMP intensity (standardized mean difference: 0.32) but showed no significant improvement in quality of life compared to control conditions. The included studies used various MT techniques, such as myofascial induction and classic massage.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer survivors with chronic musculoskeletal pain in the upper limbs and thorax.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mechanical bed massage versus rest on biochemical markers of exercise-induced back muscle fatigue in male collegiate athletes.
results_summary: Mechanical bed massage significantly reduced serum cortisol levels immediately post-intervention and creatine kinase levels 24 hours later compared to rest, but no significant differences were observed in blood lactate levels at any time point.
population_specificity: Male collegiate athletes meeting experimental criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage, cold water immersion, and passive rest on running economy and biomechanics after an exhaustive running session.
results_summary: Massage significantly improved running economy and biomechanics (stride height and angle changes) compared to passive rest and cold water immersion, particularly at higher running speeds (14 and 16 km·h⁻¹). No significant differences were observed between cold water immersion and passive rest.
population_specificity: 48 well-trained male runners
study_duration: Interventions were applied shortly after an exhaustive run, with follow-up tests at 24 and 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunflower seed oil (SSO) and mustard seed oil (MO) on skin integrity in premature and full-term neonates when used for routine massage.
results_summary: SSO showed a slightly faster decrease in skin pH compared to MO, suggesting quicker acid mantle development, but no significant differences were observed in skin condition (erythema, rash, dryness) or transepidermal water loss (TEWL) between the two oils. The effects were similar for both term and preterm infants.
population_specificity: Premature and full-term neonates in Sarlahi, Nepal.
effective_dosage: Full body massage with either SSO or MO (specific amount not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of massage (tuina-massage) as a complementary therapy for reducing depression severity in perimenopausal and menopausal women.
results_summary: Tuina-massage, particularly in combination with Chinese herbal medicine and acupuncture, showed significant benefits in reducing depression severity (measured by HRSD scores) compared to antidepressants. The effects were comparable to those of conventional treatments.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal and menopausal women with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of abdominal massage on constipation management and quality of life in older adults.
results_summary: Abdominal massage significantly improved constipation management and quality of life, with statistically significant differences in physical disability, psychosocial discomfort, anxiety, and satisfaction compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults (over 65 years old) in a nursing home with constipation based on the Rome II Diagnostic Criteria.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes/day, five days a week for eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine HIV prevalence, risk factors, and intervention gaps in Addis Ababa, with massage houses identified as one of the hotspot areas.
results_summary: The study identified massage houses as common hotspots for HIV transmission but did not specifically evaluate the safety or efficacy of massage itself.
population_specificity: Key populations (e.g., female sex workers) and general populations in Addis Ababa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of abdominal massage on reducing aspiration incidence in intensive care patients with an endotracheal tube.
results_summary: The incidence of aspiration was lower in the abdominal massage group (5.7%) compared to the control group (20%), but the difference was not statistically significant (p=0.07). The study suggests that abdominal massage may have clinical importance in reducing aspiration.
population_specificity: Intensive care patients with an endotracheal tube.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion of individuals with acute whiplash receiving evidence-based care, including massage, and whether it was associated with recovery.
results_summary: The study found that 50% of the cohort received massage as a non-recommended (passive) treatment, and evidence-based care (including massage) was not significantly associated with recovery. The therapeutic relationship, however, was linked to higher odds of recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with acute whiplash recruited from emergency departments, private physiotherapy practices, and insurance databases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize current evidence on the effectiveness of massage in reducing anxiety, pain, and improving quality-of-life for people with palliative care needs.
results_summary: The study found inconclusive evidence on the effectiveness of massage in reducing anxiety, pain, and improving quality-of-life compared to usual care or other therapies. The trials had small samples and were at an unclear risk of bias.
population_specificity: People with palliative care needs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding cervico-mandibular manual therapies to an exercise and education program improved clinical outcomes in individuals with tinnitus associated with temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The study found that combining manual therapy with exercise/education led to significantly better outcomes in TMD pain, tinnitus severity, disability, depressive symptoms, pressure pain thresholds, and mandibular range of motion compared to exercise/education alone, with large effect sizes. No significant difference was observed in quality of life (SF-12) between the groups.
population_specificity: 61 patients with tinnitus attributed to temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
effective_dosage: Six sessions of physiotherapy (including self-massage) over one month; manual therapy group received additional cervico-mandibular manual therapies.
study_duration: One month (with follow-ups at one week, three months, and six months post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency and safety of traditional Chinese medicine foot bath combined with acupoint massage for treating diabetic peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that traditional Chinese medicine foot bath combined with acupoint massage was significantly better than control groups in improving total effective rate, sensory and motor nerve conduction velocities, and neuropathic syndrome scores, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 3,284 participants with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of lavender, including massage with lavender oil, on anxiety and anxiety-related conditions.
results_summary: The study found that massage with lavender oil significantly reduced anxiety levels (Hedges' g = -0.66, p < 0.0001). However, the benefit could not be definitively attributed to lavender alone due to insufficient studies.
population_specificity: Patients with anxiety, those in anxiety-inducing settings, or undergoing anxiety-inducing activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic interventions, including massage and touch therapy, for reducing aggression and agitation in adults with dementia.
results_summary: Massage and touch therapy showed clinically significant efficacy in reducing aggression and agitation (SMD, -0.75) compared to usual care. Combining music with massage and touch therapy further enhanced efficacy (SMD, -0.91).
population_specificity: Adults with dementia exhibiting aggression and agitation.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of adjuvant laser meridian massage on heroin craving, relapse, and quality of life in men with opioid use disorder on methadone maintenance treatment.
results_summary: The study measured changes in urinary morphine levels, self-reported heroin use, craving scores, and quality of life, but results were not explicitly stated in the abstract. Statistical methods were planned to compare outcomes between the massage and control groups.
population_specificity: Fifteen men with opioid use disorder on methadone maintenance treatment.
effective_dosage: Laser meridian massage on the back (Bladder meridian and Governor Vessel) 3 times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the immediate effects of deep friction massage (DFM) on pain and muscle strength in athletes with patellar tendinopathy depend on the pressure applied during treatment.
results_summary: DFM significantly reduced pain intensity upon palpation regardless of the pressure applied, but did not significantly affect knee extensor strength or the time to onset of analgesia. The study noted caution due to the small sample size.
population_specificity: Ten athletes (mean age 27.90 years) with unilateral patellar tendinopathy.
effective_dosage: DFM applied at mean pressure and mean pressure ± 25% (individualized for each participant).
study_duration: Four sessions, each separated by 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of massage therapy in pain management and its effects on anxiety and mood changes in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy, while not directly reducing pain, can alleviate anxiety and mood changes commonly associated with pain in cancer patients. Data from randomized controlled trials support its integrative role in pain management.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of deep tissue massage, supervised strengthening and stretching exercises, and a combined therapy (exercise followed by massage) against advice to stay active for adults with subacute or persistent neck pain.
results_summary: Massage and combined therapy showed short-term improvements in pain intensity compared to advice, but no long-term benefits were observed. Perceived recovery was higher in the massage and combined therapy groups at all follow-ups, but no consistent differences were found in pain-related disability or sickness absence.
population_specificity: 619 adults with subacute or persistent neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for the use of massage as a nonpharmacological integrative therapy to improve sleep health in cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that massage is still being investigated or building its evidence base for improving sleep and insomnia in cancer survivors, suggesting limited but ongoing research support.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence-based integrative interventions, including massage, for managing psychosocial distress and stress in cancer patients and survivors.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that massage is among the integrative interventions with the largest empirical support for treating stress and psychosocial distress in cancer patients and survivors, though specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of three different surface-type foam rollers (smooth, multilevel, and GRID) on knee joint range of motion (ROM) and pressure pain threshold (PPT) of the quadriceps.
results_summary: The study found that GRID and multilevel surface rollers significantly improved knee ROM and PPT compared to the smooth roller, with the GRID roller showing the greatest effects. The improvements were statistically significant, particularly for PPT, where multilevel and GRID rollers showed substantial increases.
population_specificity: 36 participants (22 male, 14 female; mean age 25.20 ± 4.44 years) in a university laboratory setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of hand massage in reducing patient anxiety and improving comfort before cataract surgery.
results_summary: Hand massage significantly reduced anxiety (lower STAI scores) and increased comfort (lower VAS scores) compared to routine care, with positive effects on vital signs.
population_specificity: 140 patients undergoing cataract surgery (70 intervention, 70 control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic benefits of Hammam-i-Bukhari (Turkish bath) and its associated regimens, including massage, in promoting physical, psychological, and cosmetic health within the Unani system of medicine.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Hammam-i-Bukhari, combined with massage and other regimens, helps reduce viscosity of bodily humors, eliminates morbid matters, and promotes humor equilibrium, thereby enhancing overall health. The therapy is noted for its efficacy and growing popularity among patients referred by physicians.
population_specificity: Patients referred by Unani physicians, primarily in the Arab world.

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of acupoint massage combined with acupoint application on arterial blood gas and postoperative complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
results_summary: The study compared outcomes between an experimental group receiving acupoint massage and acupoint application before surgery and a control group receiving only surgery. Results suggested potential benefits in reducing postoperative complications and improving arterial blood gas parameters, though specific statistical outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (four acupuncture points were used: bilateral Hegu, Neiguan, Zusanli, and Tanzhong).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for using massage and other sensory activities within the Namaste Care intervention for people living with advanced dementia.
results_summary: The study found that various forms of touch/massage, along with other sensory interventions, appear to have proven efficacy in enhancing feelings of enjoyment and wellbeing for individuals with advanced dementia. The evidence base, though limited in quantity, supports the inclusion of these activities in Namaste Care.
population_specificity: Care home residents with advanced dementia or people at end of life with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anatomical and physiological characteristics of Inspiratory Vocal Fry (IVF) and assess its potential benefits for speech therapy and vocal pedagogy.
results_summary: IVF showed reduced false vocal folds adduction and pharyngeal wall contraction but increased vocal folds stretching compared to Expiratory Vocal Fry (EVF). Electroglottography indicated a wider vibratory cycle with improved massaging effect on vocal folds mucosa, suggesting IVF could reduce muscular hypertonic tension and enhance mucosal elasticity.
population_specificity: 32 healthy subjects (17 male, 15 female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore nonpharmacologic modalities, including massage therapy, for improving insomnia in atopic dermatitis (AD) patients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions massage therapy as a nonpharmacologic approach to improving insomnia in AD patients, but specific results or outcomes related to massage are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) experiencing sleep disturbances.

study_goal: To determine the effects of foot massage on pain during heel lancing in neonates.
results_summary: Foot massage significantly reduced pain scores during and after heel lancing compared to the control group, with no statistically significant difference between massage and acupressure.
population_specificity: Neonates in a university hospital setting.
effective_dosage: 2 minutes of massage before the procedure.
