study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physiotherapy management of GTPS (including massage) across Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland.
results_summary: Massage was used by 90% of physiotherapists as part of GTPS treatment, indicating its common inclusion in management plans, though the abstract does not detail specific efficacy outcomes for massage alone.
population_specificity: Musculoskeletal physiotherapists treating patients with GTPS in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage as a complementary therapy for pain management in children with cancer.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that massage demonstrated no significant effect on pain compared with standard care (MD, -0.77; 95% CI, -1.82, 0.28; P=0.15). It was included as one of five modalities in the decision aid for CAM treatment of pain.
population_specificity: Parents of children with cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of flexibility exercise training, including massage, compared to other interventions like aerobic training in adults with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence that flexibility exercise training, including massage, provided no clinically important benefits in health-related quality of life, pain intensity, fatigue, stiffness, and physical function compared to aerobic training. Adverse events were rarely reported, and safety remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with fibromyalgia based on published criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence rate of health-care utilization for low back pain (LBP) and identify common treatments, including massage therapy.
results_summary: Massage therapy was identified as one of the common prescriptions for managing LBP, alongside medication, exercise, and spinal manipulation. The study did not specifically evaluate the efficacy of massage but noted its frequent use in LBP management.
population_specificity: Individuals with low back pain, primarily from developed countries (USA, UK, Europe).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of physical-procedural interventions, including massage, in reducing pain during intramuscular injections.
results_summary: The study found that injection site postinjection massage, among other interventions, moderately reduced pain levels, with an overall standardized mean difference of 0.595 (95% CI = 0.417-0.773). The most effective interventions included the ventrogluteal site, the Z-technique, and manual pressure.
population_specificity: Adults receiving intramuscular injections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage and acupressure on labor-related pain management, duration, and satisfaction with delivery.
results_summary: Massage alone and combined with acupressure significantly reduced labor pain in the latent, active, and transition phases compared to the control group. The combined therapy was more effective than either therapy alone, and all interventions improved satisfaction with delivery.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in labor (n = 120).
study_duration: Duration of labor phases (latent, active, transition, and postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality of chest compressions in infant CPR using two new techniques (new two-thumb and knocking-fingers) versus the standard two-thumb-encircling hand technique.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in compression quality (depth, rate, chest release, hand position) between the standard and new techniques, with all methods achieving over 70% correct compressions. Professionals performed similarly well with all three techniques in a simulated infant manikin scenario.
population_specificity: Qualified health professionals performing CPR on an infant manikin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify effective oral health promotion programmes, including salivary massage, for improving oral health and reducing xerostomia in community-dwelling elderly.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that oral health programmes, including salivary massage, significantly increased salivary secretion rates and improved oral health-related quality of life in elderly participants.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if surface electromyography (sEMG) could objectively monitor changes in paraspinal muscle activity in acute nonspecific lower back pain (ANLBP) patients and explore the correlation between sEMG data and symptom relief after massage therapy.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly reduced pain (VAS) and improved flexibility (DFTF) in ANLBP patients while normalizing paraspinal muscle activity, as shown by changes in AEMG at different positions. The study found a significant correlation between improved muscle activity and symptom relief.
population_specificity: 45 patients with acute nonspecific lower back pain (ANLBP) and 20 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Not specified (massage therapy administered for 1 week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether depression or baseline psychological symptom frequency moderated the outcomes of massage therapy (MT) compared to simple touch in advanced cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found significant main effects of depression and baseline psychological symptom frequency on changes in pain, heart and respiratory rates, quality of life, and physical distress, but no differential responses between MT and simple touch groups. Results suggest psychological interventions could enhance outcomes for cancer patients receiving any touch therapy.
population_specificity: 380 adults with advanced cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the contribution of uterine massage and other process technologies in preventing and controlling hemorrhaging during the third stage of labor.
results_summary: The study found that uterine massage, as part of process technologies, demonstrated moderate to high evidence of effectiveness in preventing and controlling hemorrhaging, supported by 61.90% of the included papers.
population_specificity: Women in the third stage of labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the success rates of three vagal maneuvers (standard Valsalva, modified Valsalva, and carotid sinus massage) in terminating supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and maintaining sinus rhythm.
results_summary: The modified Valsalva maneuver (mVM) was significantly more effective (43.7% success rate) than the standard Valsalva (24.2%) and carotid sinus massage (9.1%) in terminating SVT. At the fifth minute, mVM also maintained sinus rhythm in 28.1% of patients, outperforming the other maneuvers.
population_specificity: Patients admitted to the emergency department and diagnosed with SVT.
effective_dosage: Not specified (vagal maneuvers were performed as interventions).
study_duration: Immediate effects measured up to the fifth minute post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short- and medium-term neurophysiological effects of massage therapy (Mss-t) and manual cranial therapy (MC-t) on autonomic activity in healthy children.
results_summary: Both Mss-t and MC-t produced short-term parasympathetic effects, but MC-t showed more persistent effects, suggesting better self-regulation and vagal control. The study concluded that MC-t might benefit autonomic imbalances in mental pathologies.
population_specificity: 50 healthy children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of device-applied and manually-applied eyelid massage techniques, combined with warm compress therapy, on ocular surface and tear film parameters in individuals with dry eye symptoms.
results_summary: Device-applied massage showed marginally greater improvements in tear film lipid layer grade compared to manual massage, though the difference was statistically but not clinically significant. No significant long-term effects or differences in other ocular parameters were observed between the two methods.
population_specificity: Twenty participants (11 females, 9 males; mean age 27 ± 11 years) with dry eye symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not specified (massage techniques applied as adjunct to 10-minute warm compress therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of self-acupoint massage (SEAM) on blood glucose levels and quality of life in older adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: SEAM significantly reduced HbA1c levels and improved quality of life scores in older adults with T2DM after 12 weeks of intervention compared to routine nursing alone.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of massage with and without violet oil on uremic pruritus in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Massage with violet oil significantly improved skin dryness, pruritus severity, location, and frequency compared to massage alone, with both interventions showing notable recovery.
population_specificity: 57 hemodialysis patients with uremic pruritus.
effective_dosage: 5 ml violet oil applied topically for 7 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how somatosensory stimulation, including massage, affects skeletal muscle blood flow and its potential benefits for muscle disorders.
results_summary: The study found that somatosensory stimulation, such as massage, can increase skeletal muscle blood flow, which may improve conditions like muscle stiffness and pain. The effects vary depending on whether the response is systemic (reflex pressor) or localized (antidromic and local vasodilation).
population_specificity: Anesthetized animals (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of instrument-assisted soft tissue mobilization (IASTM) in improving range of motion, pain, strength, and patient-reported function, and to provide recommendations for its use.
results_summary: The study found large effect sizes for improving range of motion in uninjured individuals and for reducing pain and improving patient-reported function in injured patients. Different IASTM tools showed similar effect sizes across outcomes.
population_specificity: Both injured and uninjured participants were studied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore women's perceptions of Rhythmical Massage (RM) as a therapeutic intervention for primary dysmenorrhea (PD) and its impact on body awareness and daily life limitations.
results_summary: The study found that RM, along with HRV-BF, improved self-awareness and body perception, sometimes reducing daily life limitations for women with PD. Effects varied, with some women reporting significant benefits on physical, emotional, and social levels, while others experienced only relaxation without symptom relief.
population_specificity: 60 women with primary dysmenorrhea (14 analyzed qualitatively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a prenatal-to-age-five intervention, including baby massage, on the home environment and children's cognitive and emotional development.
results_summary: The intervention improved aspects of the home environment (e.g., learning material, environmental variety, acceptance of behaviors) but these changes did not mediate improvements in children's outcomes. Baby massage was part of the broader intervention, but its individual effects were not isolated.
population_specificity: Pregnant women from a disadvantaged Irish community and their children up to age five.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of physical modalities, including massage, in managing pain and improving mobility in patients with metastatic bone disease or multiple myeloma.
results_summary: The study noted that modalities increasing local blood flow, such as massage, are not performed at the tumor site, but did not provide specific efficacy or safety data for massage.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic bone disease or multiple myeloma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether classical massage could reduce chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy and improve quality of life in breast cancer patients receiving adjuvant paclitaxel.
results_summary: The study found that classical massage significantly reduced peripheral neuropathic pain, improved quality of life (particularly sensory and motor sub-scales), and showed beneficial effects on nerve conduction studies compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer patients receiving adjuvant paclitaxel.
effective_dosage: Applied before each paclitaxel infusion (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 16 weeks (assessments at baseline and weeks 4, 8, 12, and 16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine factors influencing the concordance between cancer patients' preferred and received life-sustaining treatments, including cardiac massage, in their last six months of life.
results_summary: The study found poor concordance (40.8%) between preferred and received life-sustaining treatments, with prognostic awareness and preferred treatment states significantly influencing outcomes. Cardiac massage was one of the treatments assessed, but no specific efficacy or safety results for massage were highlighted.
population_specificity: 218 Taiwanese cancer patients in their last six months of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a mouth-opening intervention, including masticatory muscle massage, on postoperative trismus and mandibular function in oral cancer surgery patients, and the impact of remote telephone support on adherence.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention program, including massage, significantly improved maximum interincisal opening and reduced mandibular function impairment, with greater adherence and outcomes in the group receiving additional telephone support.
population_specificity: Patients admitted for oral cancer surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included warm compress, masticatory muscle massage, and jaw exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of breast massage in reducing pain, increasing milk supply, and resolving symptoms like blocked ducts, engorgement, and mastitis in breastfeeding women.
results_summary: The review found that breast massage reduced immediate pain and helped resolve symptoms, but methodological limitations (heterogeneity, small sample sizes, unvalidated tools) reduced generalizability and overall effectiveness.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding women of any age, parity, or geographical location experiencing breastfeeding problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of olive oil massage on reducing the severity of uremic restless legs syndrome (RLS).
results_summary: The study found a significant decline in RLS severity in the olive oil massage group compared to the placebo group, with notable improvements in both total severity and specific categories of RLS. The effects were more pronounced in the olive oil group, suggesting its efficacy as a complementary therapy.
population_specificity: 60 patients with uremic RLS (mean age: 51.96 ± 10.15).
effective_dosage: 10 mL of olive oil per leg, massaged for five minutes, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability and responsiveness of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) for neck pain after physiotherapy, including massage, in patients with acute whiplash injury.
results_summary: The study found that the Neck Bournemouth Questionnaire (NBQ) was the most reliable and responsive measure of change after physiotherapy, which included massage. All PROMs showed high reliability, with the NBQ being significantly more responsive than others.
population_specificity: 86 patients with neck pain referred for physiotherapy within 2 weeks of whiplash injury.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment included deep soft tissue massage, myofascial releases, muscle energy techniques, joint articulation, and manipulation techniques, plus a home exercise program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bulbar urethral massage and pelvic floor exercises in treating post-micturition dribble (PMD).
results_summary: The study found that bulbar urethral massage and pelvic floor exercises are effective in treating PMD, though pharmacologic treatments have not yet been introduced. PMD is associated with pelvic floor muscle weakness and may overlap with other lower urinary tract symptoms and erectile dysfunction.
population_specificity: Males with post-micturition dribble (PMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of self-administered acupressure for managing allergic rhinitis (AR).
results_summary: The study design suggests potential benefits of acupressure for AR, but results are pending as the abstract describes a proposed trial rather than completed findings. The trial will assess symptom severity, quality of life, medication use, and adverse events.
population_specificity: Allergic rhinitis (AR) sufferers.
effective_dosage: 1 minute per acupressure point, twice daily for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of massage and other complementary integrative therapies in managing cancer-related pain within a multidisciplinary approach.
results_summary: Massage, among other mind-body therapies, was found to be efficient in addressing cancer pain by acting on anxiety, stress, depression, or mood disturbances. However, the sustainability of outcomes for most complementary integrative therapies, including massage, remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer-related pain, including specific subgroups like head and neck or breast cancer patients, and cancer survivors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a self-management program, including massage, on preventing breast cancer-related lymphedema and improving quality of life.
results_summary: The intervention group, which included massage as part of the self-management program, showed no lymphedema development, while 61.2% of the control group developed lymphedema. The intervention group also had higher quality of life and lower symptom scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (n=61)

study_goal: To systematically review the effects of soft tissue mobilization (STM) on symptoms related to both surgical and non-surgical abdominal adhesions.
results_summary: The review found preliminary strong evidence for STM's benefits on acute post-surgical adhesion symptoms, moderate evidence for chronic non-surgical adhesion symptoms (fertility and SBO), and moderate evidence for chronic post-surgical adhesion symptoms. Improvements included reduced pain, better quality of life, function, scar mobility, and decreased medication use.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 10.7 to 89.4 years with abdominal adhesion-related symptoms (surgical and non-surgical).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the strength of evidence for therapeutic massage as a nonpharmacological option for pain management, comparing it with other CIH therapies.
results_summary: The study found that massage has statistically significant positive effects on some types of pain, though firm conclusions for many pain types are limited by methodological issues or lack of RCTs. Individual studies suggest massage may be promising for multiple types of chronic pain.
population_specificity: Not specified (general pain populations, likely including chronic pain and headache).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of sensory-based interventions, including massage, for clients with dementia and Alzheimer's disease in residential facilities.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence supporting the use of massage as an effective intervention for clients with dementia and Alzheimer's disease. Other sensory-based interventions showed moderate to inconclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Clients with dementia and Alzheimer's disease living in residential facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether psychological interventions, including massage, could enhance the antibody response to vaccination.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence of benefit, with some trials showing improved antibody responses to vaccination, but effects were inconsistent across outcomes and time points. Adequate adherence to the intervention appeared to increase the likelihood of benefit.
population_specificity: 1603 participants across 9 trials, with 3 trials specifically involving massage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify nursing interventions, including massage, in palliative care for children and adolescents with cancer.
results_summary: The study found that massage, among other interventions, showed better results when targeting specific symptoms compared to broader palliative care approaches.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cancer receiving palliative care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences, perceived benefits, harms, and preferred delivery methods of massage among people with advanced disease, particularly cancer.
results_summary: The study found that massage provided benefits such as enhanced well-being, respite, and escapism from the disease. Participants valued the therapy and its delivery, suggesting it should be developed in consultation with the target population.
population_specificity: People with advanced cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combined massage therapy and phototherapy on neonatal jaundice.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention significantly decreased bilirubin levels, increased urination, and reduced hospitalization duration in full-term infants with hyperbilirubinemia.
population_specificity: Healthy full-term infants with neonatal jaundice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Qigong (including Qigong massage) in reducing symptoms of autism spectrum disorder in children.
results_summary: Studies indicated that Qigong showed promising effects in reducing sensory, behavioral, and language symptoms of autism, improving self-control, sociability, and cognitive awareness. However, methodological quality was insufficient to recommend it as a primary treatment.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-17 years with autism spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of hand massage and therapeutic touch on comfort and anxiety levels in elderly nursing home residents.
results_summary: The study found that both hand massage and therapeutic touch significantly reduced anxiety and increased comfort levels in the elderly (p < 0.05), with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 65-89 living in a nursing home in Izmir, Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the literature on physical therapist-delivered interventions, including massage, for reducing pain among older adults with dementia.
results_summary: Massage showed pain-reducing effects in one study compared with no treatment, while passive movement did not demonstrate significant benefits. The overall evidence supporting physical therapy interventions for pain reduction in dementia patients was limited.
population_specificity: Older adults (60+ years) with medically diagnosed dementia of any severity (mean age range = 82.2-84.0 years; 80.2% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage and aromatherapy massage improve sleep quality in cardiac patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in sleep quality (measured by PSQI) in both massage and aromatherapy massage groups compared to the control group, though no significant difference was observed between the two intervention groups.
population_specificity: Cardiac patients with sleep disorders.
effective_dosage: Hands and feet massage using sweet almond oil (massage group) or a mixture of lavender and sweet almond oil (aromatherapy massage group). Frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of topical sesame oil combined with massage in reducing pain severity in patients with chemotherapy-induced phlebitis (CIP).
results_summary: The study found that massage with sesame oil significantly reduced pain severity compared to massage alone, with notable improvements by the third day and sustained effects through the seventh day. Both groups showed pain reduction, but the experimental group (sesame oil + massage) had superior outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 patients with colorectal cancer afflicted with chemotherapy-induced phlebitis.
effective_dosage: 10 drops of sesame oil applied twice daily during a 5-minute massage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nature sounds, foot sole reflexology massage, and their combination on the level of consciousness in traumatic comatose patients.
results_summary: The study found that single or combined interventions (nature sounds and foot reflexology massage) significantly increased the number of patients who regained full consciousness and reduced the duration of coma compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 120 traumatic comatose patients in Iran.
effective_dosage: Interventions were performed twice a day for 30 minutes each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if massage reduces short-term physiological and clinical effects of muscle fatigue in individuals with nonspecific chronic low back pain (cLBP) and to study associations between physiological and clinical changes.
results_summary: Massage significantly reduced pain perception in cLBP individuals but did not influence pain increases after physical exertion. It had no significant effect on fatigue-related physiological variables.
population_specificity: Individuals with nonspecific chronic low back pain (cLBP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of fascia in health curricula and demonstrate its relevance across various medical disciplines.
results_summary: The abstract emphasizes the growing recognition of fascia's roles in pathology, fluid movement, proprioception, pain perception, and systemic connectivity, advocating for its integration into health education without additional coursework.
population_specificity: Healthcare professional students and residents across medical, veterinary, dental, physical therapy, physician assistant, and occupational therapy disciplines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute autonomic responses to connective tissue manipulation (CTM) in healthy young women with varying physical activity levels.
results_summary: The study found that CTM significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure and increased respiratory rate in healthy young women, with effects varying slightly based on physical activity levels. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Healthy women aged 18-25 years with varying physical activity levels.
effective_dosage: Not specified (single session of CTM applied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the methods and findings of the 2016 DoD Warrior Games surveillance system, including the use of integrative medicine treatments like massage therapy.
results_summary: Massage therapy was among the most common treatments (31% of all treatments), indicating its frequent use for injury and illness management in the studied population. No specific efficacy outcomes for massage were detailed, but its inclusion as a major treatment suggests perceived benefits.
population_specificity: Wounded warrior athletes (245 participants) from Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Special Operations, and United Kingdom teams.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of friction massage techniques on the pronator teres muscle regarding supination range of motion (ROM) and supinator strength in individuals with and without limited supination ROM.
results_summary: Friction massage significantly increased supination ROM in both the limited supination group and the control group. It also immediately increased supinator muscle strength in the limited supination group, though no significant interaction effect was observed for strength overall.
population_specificity: 26 subjects (13 with limited supination ROM and 13 healthy controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if massage therapy reduces pain and perceived fatigue in the quadriceps, improves mood, and enhances physical performance in runners after a 10-km run.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly reduced pain intensity by a small margin (0.7 points on a 0-10 scale) compared to a sham technique, but showed no significant effects on perceived fatigue, flexibility, strength, or jump performance.
population_specificity: Seventy-eight runners after a 10-km run.
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of massage to the quadriceps.
study_duration: Single session, with follow-up evaluations at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of wrist joint splinting combined with physical therapy (including deep friction massage) versus standard physical therapy alone in improving pain, wrist ROM, and grip strength in lateral epicondylitis patients.
results_summary: The intervention group (splinting + physical therapy) showed statistically significant improvements in pain intensity, wrist flexion ROM, wrist extension ROM, and grip strength compared to the standard care group (physical therapy alone). Deep friction massage was part of the standard care protocol but its isolated effects were not separately analyzed.
population_specificity: Forty participants diagnosed with lateral epicondylitis.
effective_dosage: Deep friction massage was administered 3 times per week (specific duration per session not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore perceptions and experiences of labour companionship, including the role of massage as a form of practical support during childbirth.
results_summary: The study found that labour companions provided practical support, including massage, which contributed to a positive birth experience for women. However, confidence in some findings, such as the impact of male partners or doulas, was low.
population_specificity: Women in labour, their partners, family members, doulas, healthcare providers, and administrators across various global settings, predominantly high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current treatment and preventive strategies, including massage, for delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS).
results_summary: The abstract indicates that massage is among the interventions studied for DOMS, but it does not specify the efficacy or outcomes of massage compared to other treatments. The focus is on broader strategies for preventing and alleviating DOMS symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals experiencing DOMS, particularly athletes or those engaging in unaccustomed or eccentric exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 2-week massage intervention conducted by mothers on the growth of preterm infants in the NICU.
results_summary: The study found that preterm infants who received the massage intervention showed significant increases in weight, height, and head circumference compared to the control group. The intervention was effective, with statistically significant improvements (p < .001) across all measured growth parameters.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born at a gestational age between 32 and 34 weeks in a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).
effective_dosage: Massage intervention included: (i) prone position (5 + 5 min), (ii) supine position (5 min), performed slowly and with controlled strength.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review evidence on the effects of massage on physiological and psychological outcomes in adult critically ill patients.
results_summary: The review found favorable effects of massage, including improvements in vital signs, reductions in pain and anxiety, and high internal validity in 8 of 12 randomized control studies. However, gaps remain in assessing sleep quality, analgesic/sedative dosages, and level of consciousness.
population_specificity: Adult critically ill patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aromatherapy massage versus common massage alone in improving anxiety among patients receiving palliative care.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in anxiety improvement between aromatherapy massage and common massage alone, with a mean difference of -2.60 (95% CI: -7.82, 2.63, P = .33). The results suggest aromatherapy massage does not provide additional benefits over common massage for anxiety relief in this population.
population_specificity: Patients receiving palliative care.

study_goal: The abstract does not specifically study massage but mentions it as a nonpharmacologic option for labor pain management.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about massage, only noting it as a potential adjunct or alternative for labor pain relief.
population_specificity: Women in labor (general mention, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and treatment effect estimates of a multimodal integrative intervention (including moderate pressure touch massage) for preventing critical illness delirium and related outcomes in ICU patients.
results_summary: The study evaluated feasibility outcomes like recruitment rates and protocol adherence, with the primary clinical outcome being delirium incidence (ICDSC ≥4). Secondary outcomes included pain scores, inflammatory biomarkers, and stress levels, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 104 ICU patients (ages 18-64 and ≥65) with ICDSC scores of 0-3, recruited from two academic intensive care units.
study_duration: Up to five consecutive days (or until transfer/discharge)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether routine use of intravenous oxytocin reduces the need for interventions like uterine massage to control excess bleeding during dilation and evacuation (D&E) at 18-24 weeks of gestation.
results_summary: Oxytocin did not significantly reduce the frequency of interventions for bleeding (primary outcome) but did decrease blood loss, hemorrhage frequency, and procedure duration compared to placebo. No differences were found in non-hemorrhage complications, pain scores, or satisfaction between groups.
population_specificity: Women undergoing D&E at 18-24 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: 30 units of oxytocin in 500 mL of intravenous fluid.
study_duration: Administered during the procedure (median duration: 11.0 minutes in oxytocin group vs. 13.5 minutes in placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map the neurophysiological impacts of human touch (including massage) and eye gaze, particularly their relevance to therapeutic relationships and healing.
results_summary: The review found consistent trends indicating beneficial neurophysiological effects of touch (with massage predominating), primarily measured through cortisol, oxytocin, and noradrenaline levels, though clinical context studies were limited.
population_specificity: Cognitively intact human subjects in various settings, with few involving clinicians (nurses) and patients.

study_goal: To develop evidence-based guidelines for the non-pharmacological management of persistent headaches associated with neck pain, including the role of clinical massage.
results_summary: The study found that clinical massage can be considered as part of multimodal care for chronic tension-type headaches, though it was not evaluated as a standalone treatment. The guideline emphasizes patient-centered care and structured education alongside interventions.
population_specificity: Adults with persistent headaches associated with neck pain (tension-type or cervicogenic headaches).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and safety of ductal lavage combined with breast massage as a novel treatment for nonlactational mastitis (NLM).
results_summary: Ductal lavage significantly reduced pain scores and mastitis severity, with 93.8% of patients achieving complete response within a median of 6 months. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 32 patients with nonlactational mastitis (idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, periductal mastitis, or unspecific NLM).
effective_dosage: Intraductal infusion of corticosteroids and antimicrobial agents followed by breast massage the next day, repeated for 2 weeks.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up for 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of manual massage as a non-pharmacological treatment for behavioral and psychological symptoms in persons living with dementia.
results_summary: The study found that manual massage showed significant benefits in reducing agitation (Cohen Mansfield Agitation Inventory) and depressive symptoms (Cornell Scale of Depression in Dementia), but no significant effects were observed for cognitive abilities (Mini Mental State Examination) or other neuropsychiatric symptoms (Neuropsychiatric Inventory).
population_specificity: Persons living with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dry needling and friction massage in reducing headache frequency and intensity in patients with tension-type headache (TTH).
results_summary: Both dry needling and friction massage significantly reduced headache frequency and intensity and increased pain threshold at trigger points, with no significant differences between the two treatments except for pain threshold, where dry needling was superior. Neither treatment affected cervical range of motion except for extension, which improved with dry needling.
population_specificity: 44 patients with tension-type headache (TTH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of upper thoracic spine mobilization, posterior shoulder massage/mobilization/stretching, and an active control intervention on pain and function in individuals with extrinsic subacromial shoulder impingement (SSI).
results_summary: Both upper thoracic and posterior shoulder interventions significantly reduced pain, improved function scores, and increased posterior shoulder range compared to the active control at 12 weeks and 6 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals with clearly defined extrinsic subacromial shoulder impingement (SSI).
effective_dosage: Nine treatments over 6 weeks, followed by daily home exercises for 6 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks (6 weeks of treatment + 6 weeks of home exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the side effects and physical harm of massage during pregnancy and the postnatal period, as well as its benefits for conditions like low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that 40% of participants experienced post-massage side effects, but no physical harm to mother or child was reported. Massage significantly reduced stress, pain, and improved range of motion and sleep.
population_specificity: Pregnant and postnatal women seeking massage therapy in Sydney and Melbourne.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current evidence on the effects and safety of massage therapy for treating ADHD in children and adolescents.
results_summary: Pooled analysis showed massage improved ADHD symptoms more effectively than Ritalin, with significant improvements in anxious-passive and asocial behaviors compared to waitlist controls.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of rhythmical massage compared to heart rate variability biofeedback and usual care in reducing pain intensity in women with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Rhythmical massage showed a significant reduction in pain intensity compared to usual care after three months, with no significant differences between massage and biofeedback or between biofeedback and usual care. Secondary outcomes (analgesic use, quality of life, heart rate variability) showed no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Women with primary dysmenorrhea (mean age 29.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tuina and traditional Chinese massage in treating pain and disability in adults with chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study will evaluate changes in pain and disability using validated measures (Northwick Park Neck Pain Questionnaire, VAS, NDI, SF-36), but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The trial is designed to clarify the comparative efficacy of the two massage interventions.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic neck pain (356 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) combined with conservative treatment was more effective than attention-control massage treatment combined with conservative treatment for adults with fecal incontinence.
results_summary: The study found that supervised PFMT was significantly more effective than attention-control massage treatment in improving fecal incontinence symptoms, with participants in the PFMT group reporting 5-fold higher odds of improvement and a larger reduction in incontinence severity. No significant differences were found in condition-specific quality of life between the two groups.
population_specificity: Adults with fecal incontinence at a tertiary care center in Denmark.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage therapy improves scar elasticity, erythema, melanin, and thickness in hypertrophic scars compared to control scars over a 12-week period.
results_summary: The study found short-term changes in scar characteristics after massage, but no significant long-term benefits in elasticity, erythema, or thickness compared to control scars. Group differences in erythema were noted at weeks 8 and 11, with control scars being less erythematous than massage-treated scars.
population_specificity: Burn survivors with hypertrophic scars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of whole-body massage on knee osteoarthritis compared to light-touch and usual care, focusing on symptom relief and safety.
results_summary: At 8 weeks, massage significantly improved WOMAC Global scores, pain, stiffness, and physical function compared to light-touch and usual care. By 52 weeks, no significant differences were observed between groups, though massage maintained improvements without additional benefit over usual care.
population_specificity: Adults with knee osteoarthritis (222 enrolled, 175 completed 52-week assessments).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes of full-body massage or light-touch, eight weekly treatments followed by biweekly intervention or usual care.
study_duration: 52 weeks (initial 8-week intensive phase, followed by maintenance phase).
